user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_close_error:
```c
static void
connection_close_error (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                        const char *emsg)
{
  connection->stop_with_error = true;
  connection->discard_request = true;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if (NULL != emsg)
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              "%s\n",
              emsg);
#else  /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  (void) emsg; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  MHD_connection_close_ (connection,
                         MHD_REQUEST_TERMINATED_WITH_ERROR);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments modify the function parameters themselves. The function parameters are:
- connection (type: struct MHD_Connection *): only members of the pointed-to object are modified (connection->stop_with_error and connection->discard_request). Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by Rule 17.8; only changing the pointer variable (e.g. assigning to connection) would violate the rule. There is no assignment to the pointer variable.
- emsg (type: const char *): it is only tested against NULL, passed to MHD_DLOG, and explicitly cast to void to silence a warning. None of these actions modify the pointer variable or the pointee. Also, passing the pointer to another function does not count as modifying the parameter within this function.
- The call to MHD_connection_close_(connection, ...) passes the pointer but does not reassign the parameter inside this function. Any effects inside the called function do not constitute modification of this function's parameter variable.
Therefore, there are no fragments in this code that warrant investigation for a Rule 17.8 violation.
